title: Boeing wants to double in size, and Australia is central to its plan
text:
“Our outlook says in the next 20 years 44,000 new aeroplanes are going to be bought and that’s about double the current world fleet.

“The key point for Australia is that the highest proportion of these are coming to the Asia Pacific – 17,000 aeroplanes, which means this is the marketplace.”

Boeing's corporate plan states the company wants to double in size by 2025.

Sir Michael said Boeing’s operations in Australia had benefited from several breakthroughs in locally sourced research and development which was being applied in the plants in Melbourne and Brisbane.

The Melbourne operation, which is called Boeing Aerostructures Australia, won Australia’s largest aerospace contract valued at $5 billion over 20 years. It is a Tier 1 partner for the Boeing 787 Dreamliner program.

Sir Michael said Fishermans Bend was the only Boeing location in the world to apply the unique resin-infusion system that enables the components to be cured without a traditional autoclave.

“When building that plant we put in a whole bunch of research scientists cheek by jowl with the engineers so there is a synergy between the new research and the production,” he said.

In Brisbane, Boeing is building a prototype of an unmanned aircraft designed to fly in groups alongside manned fighter jets. It is called the Boeing Airpower Teaming System and was first revealed at the Avalon air show in February.

“It’s a very exciting new venture for us which was designed and conceived in Australia in partnership with the Australian Defence Forces,” Sir Michael said.

“We’re looking to see if we can’t use it from here as an export to other countries.”

Twin tragedies

It has been a tough 12 months for Boeing because of the fallout from the accidents involving two separate 737 MAX aircraft operated by Lion Air and Ethiopian Airlines.

“We have just been totally focused on how we can get out from that problem because safety is paramount and it has been for 100 years,” he said. "We are sharpening our focus and realigning internal resources to really strengthen the culture of safety that we have."

Boeing chairman and chief executive Dennis Muilenburg and the Boeing board of directors commissioned a five-month independent review of the company’s policies and processes for aircraft design and development.

In response to the review, Sir Michael said Boeing had tightened its oversight of engineers by creating a new product and services safety organisation which reports directly to the chief engineer who, in turn, reports to Mr Muilenburg.
description: Boeing, the $200 billion aircraft maker, is using advanced manufacturing techniques at its plants in Melbourne and Brisbane to boost exports of products for the civil aviation market and possibly for military customers.
